detailed_results.reasoning: The input and gold formula negate the coalition ability: it is NOT the case that robots 1,2,3 can enforce G pos1. The prediction omits the outer negation and instead asserts they can enforce it, which is the opposite meaning.

detailed_results.input: The world’s stable now. People are happy; they get what they want, and they never want what they can’t get. They’re well off; they’re safe; they’re never ill; they’re not afraid of death; they’re blissfully ignorant of passion and old age; they’re plagued with no mothers or fathers; they’ve got no wives, or children, or lovers to feel strongly about; they’re so conditioned that they practically can’t help behaving as they ought to behave.
detailed_results.prediction: <<World>>G stability && people_happy && (desire <-> can_get) && well_off && safe && never_ill && not_afraid_of_death && ignorant_of_passion && ignorant_of_old_age && no_parents && no_wives && no_children && not_in_love
detailed_results.reasoning: Gold states only that the World can ensure stability always (<<World>>G stable). The prediction strengthens the property by conjoining many additional non-temporal propositions (and also uses G only on stability, not on the other claims). This changes the expressed requirement, so it is not semantically equivalent to the gold formula.

detailed_results.input: If we wish to fight, the enemy can be forced to an engagement even though he be sheltered behind a high rampart and a deep ditch. All we need do is attack some other place that he will be obliged to relieve.
detailed_results.reasoning: Prediction changes both structure and meaning. Gold is a simple implication from the enemy being sheltered (high rampart and deep ditch) to us attacking another place. Prediction instead states globally that if 'engage' holds then eventually the enemy will relieve, introducing G and F, different propositions, and reversing the conditional content; it does not express forcing engagement by attacking elsewhere.
